title: 114_hr1218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Personal Health Investment Today Act" or the "PHIT Act." Congress finds that almost 20 percent of American children aged 2 to 19 are overweight or obese, leading to increased healthcare costs. Investing in physical activity could significantly reduce medical expenses, with research showing that financial incentives could encourage more Americans to be active. The Act aims to promote health by encouraging healthier lifestyles, providing financial incentives for healthy behavior, and increasing access to physical fitness activities. The United States ranks last in reducing preventable deaths from obesity-related illnesses, highlighting the importance of early engagement in physical activities for long-term health benefits. Certain amounts paid for physical activity, fitness, and exercise are treated as amounts paid for medical care. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses to be considered as amounts paid for medical care. This includes membership at a fitness facility, participation in physical exercise programs, and equipment for such programs. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses, including membership at a fitness facility, participation in physical exercise programs, and equipment for such programs, with an overall dollar limitation of $1,000 per taxpayer ($2,000 for joint returns or heads of household). The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses, including membership at a fitness facility that meets specific criteria. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses, including membership at a fitness facility that meets specific criteria. Exercise videos, books, and similar materials are treated as described if they provide instruction in physical exercise. Amounts paid for sports and fitness equipment are qualified expenses only if used exclusively for fitness participation. Qualified sports and fitness expenses include equipment used exclusively for fitness, exercise, sports, or physical activity programs, excluding apparel or footwear. For sports equipment, the amount paid must not exceed $250. Rules similar to section 213(d)(6) apply to programs with components other than physical exercise. The amendments made by this section, regarding the rules of section 213(d)(6), apply to programs with physical exercise or activity and other components. Travel and accommodations are considered as other components. Effective date is for taxable years after enactment of the Act.
